title: How to Make Ice Cream Quickly

steps.headline: Once you have all your ingredients, put 3 tablespoons of sugar, the cup of half-and-half and a teaspoon of vanilla extract in a pint-sized baggie.
steps.description: If you are creating another flavor, add correctly proportioned, preferred ingredient(s) in the bag as well.

steps.headline: Seal the bag tightly or there will be a sticky cleanup soon to follow.
steps.description: Ensure that there is no air in the bag after you seal it. It is helpful to note that mixing the ingredients during this stage is crucial to achieving yumminess.

steps.headline: Combine 1/2 cup of salt and the ice cubes in the gallon bag.
steps.description: Ensure that the ice fills up only half of the bag.

steps.headline: Add pint-sized bag of ingredients from previous steps into the ice and salt mixture.
Seal the bag like a quarantine tent during an epidemic.
steps.description: This ensures that you don't lose everything during the next step.

steps.headline: Using your hands, shake and mix the entire thing.
steps.description: Grabbing the sides of the bag makes it easier to shake. Wearing warm gloves is recommended here because the ice gets pretty cold.

steps.headline: After about five minutes of shaking and mixing, feel the small bag to determine whether or not it’s finished.
steps.description: In order to determine this, the ice cream mixture will have the consistency of a slightly softer version of store bought ice cream, or a Frosty™.

steps.headline: Once the ice cream is done remove the smaller bag from the large bag.
steps.description: Open the larger bag over the sink as the ice and salt mixture could stain your average kitchen surface. It is recommended to wear rubber gloves at this point as salt and ice creates a powerful chemical reaction that can physically harm your skin.

steps.headline: Once separated, you can eat the ice cream right out of the bag or place it into a bowl/cone to enjoy.
High five your best friend because you just created your own ice cream.

text: Once you have all your ingredients, put 3 tablespoons of sugar, the cup of half-and-half and a teaspoon of vanilla extract in a pint-sized baggie. If you are creating another flavor, add correctly proportioned, preferred ingredient(s) in the bag as well. Seal the bag tightly or there will be a sticky cleanup soon to follow. Ensure that there is no air in the bag after you seal it. It is helpful to note that mixing the ingredients during this stage is crucial to achieving yumminess. Combine 1/2 cup of salt and the ice cubes in the gallon bag. Ensure that the ice fills up only half of the bag. Add pint-sized bag of ingredients from previous steps into the ice and salt mixture.  Seal the bag like a quarantine tent during an epidemic. This ensures that you don't lose everything during the next step. Using your hands, shake and mix the entire thing. Grabbing the sides of the bag makes it easier to shake. Wearing warm gloves is recommended here because the ice gets pretty cold. After about five minutes of shaking and mixing, feel the small bag to determine whether or not it’s finished. In order to determine this, the ice cream mixture will have the consistency of a slightly softer version of store bought ice cream, or a Frosty™. Once the ice cream is done remove the smaller bag from the large bag. Open the larger bag over the sink as the ice and salt mixture could stain your average kitchen surface. It is recommended to wear rubber gloves at this point as salt and ice creates a powerful chemical reaction that can physically harm your skin. Once separated, you can eat the ice cream right out of the bag or place it into a bowl/cone to enjoy. Add toppings if desired. High five your best friend because you just created your own ice cream.  Finished.
